pageData.text: In this investigation, you will observe the wide array of microscopic life that comprises protists. You will first examine prepared microscope slides, then prepare a hay infusion medium to culture protists from a local water source. You will then examine wet mount slides of the cultured protists and identify them.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
pageData.text:
• Paper or printed drawing template
  • Colored pencils
  • Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation: Microscope Tutorial – 15 minutes 
Activity 1: Observing Prepared Slides – 100 minutes
Activity 2: Hay Infusion and Wet Mount of Cultured Microorganisms – 15 minutes
Activity 3: Observing Cultured Microorganisms – 60 minutes

text: Identify the characteristics that define protists.
Demonstrate microscopy skills by observing and drawing protists.

pageData.text: Giant kelp looks like a plant, but it is a type of brown algae and is classified as a protist. The giant kelp is the largest of the marine algae. Under perfect conditions, it can grow 11-24 inches a day and reach a height of almost 200 feet. It is a photosynthetic organism that lives in cold ocean water, forming large, dense kelp forests that are an important habitat for thousands of marine species. For example, sea otters sleep on their backs on the surface of the water, but to prevent themselves from floating away, they wrap themselves up in giant kelp while they sleep.

Giant kelp forests are important because they not only provide a home for a wide array of marine vertebrates and invertebrates, but also help protect beaches. Giant kelp forests reduce the force of storm-driven tides and surges moving toward land. They prevent erosion and act as a fence to retain nearshore sand. Giant kelp forests also absorb and hold carbon, a process called carbon sequestration. Efforts to conserve and restore giant kelp forests are underway, with the hope of combating global climate change.

pageData.altText: A view looking up through a kelp forset in the ocean. Streams of sun light pentrate through the leaves.
pageData.desc: A view looking up through a kelp forset in the ocean. Streams of sun light pentrate through the leaves.

pageData.text: Protists are eukaryotic organisms that are typically found in fresh or marine water or moist environments. The term “protist” refers to all members of the former kingdom Protista. The kingdom was formerly composed of primarily single-celled organisms that did not fit into the kingdoms Animalia (animals), Plantae (plants), Fungi (fungus), or Monera (bacteria). Kingdom Protista was divided into animal-like, plant-like, or fungi-like protists; however, there were many protists that did not fit neatly into these three categories. Today, modern classification systems based on molecular genetics have changed the classification schemes for many organisms. Protists are no longer considered a valid kingdom, and the term is mainly used out of convenience to refer to those eukaryotic organisms that are not plants, animals, or fungi. Protists are , meaning that all of the members of the group have a common ancestor, but the group does not necessarily include all of the descendants of that ancestor.

pageData.subTitle: Nutrition
pageData.text: Protists obtain their nutrition in many different ways. Some protists, such as algae, are , which produce food (glucose) through photosynthesis. Others are , which obtain food from their environment. Heterotrophic protists can either absorb nutrients, as is the case with slime molds such as Myxogastria, or they can engulf other organisms, as is the case with Amoeba. Some ciliates and flagellates use their appendages to filterfeed, using them to create water currents that help them to engulf their food. Some protists are able to both produce food and obtain food from their environment. These protists, such as Euglena, are called mixotrophs.

pageData.subTitle: Movement
pageData.text: Motile protists can use one of three main methods of locomotion: cilia, flagella, or . Cilia are short, hair-like projections that are typically found all around the cell. Movement of the cilia allows protists to move in the desired direction or to create water currents, directing food and other nutrients into a cavity for absorption. Flagella are long projections that are moved in a whip-like motion to propel the protist in the desired direction. Pseudopodia are temporary projections of the cytoplasm and cell membrane that are extended from the cell-like feet, moving the protist. Pseudopodia can be lobe-like, as with Amoeba, or hair-like, as with the .

pageData.subTitle: Classification
pageData.text: Protists have been classified in many different ways. Currently, scientists are working on classification schemes based on the molecular evidence. Because of this, many changes are occurring in cladistics. Origins for each of the other eukaryotic kingdoms can be found within these groups. This is a rapidly changing and hotly contested area of . The following represent one method of classifying protists based on a synthesis of traditional phylogenies and new genetic evidence:

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A micrograph of a long thin Euglena cell curled into a C-shape. Within the cell, many green internal cell structures are visible.

pageData.text: A. get their name from the feeding groove located on one side of the cell; however, many members of this group have lost this structure and are classified as Excavata based on their genes. In many Excavates, are missing or reduced in number. Some members of this group are animal parasites, and others, such as some euglenids (Figure 1), are photosynthetic. The photosynthetic ability arises from a with green algae. Secondary endosymbiosis occurs when one organism (such as a protist) engulfs another organism (such as green algae) that over evolutionary time becomes part of and necessary for the life of the original organism. Giardia (Figure 2), Trichomonas, and Euglena are classified as Excavates.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Scanning electron micrograph (SEM) of a flagellated Giardia lamblia.

pageData.text: B. have undergone with red algae. Some Chromalveolates are multicellular. The major groups are:

are characterized by the presence of (small membrane-bound cavities). Within this group are the ciliates, which use cilia to move; the dinoflagellates, which use flagella to move; and the Apicomplexans, which are obligate parasites. Some Alveolates are photosynthetic, some have remnants of photosynthetic organelles but are no longer photosynthetic, and others demonstrate no evidence of ever having possessed a photosynthetic organelle. Paramecium (Figure 3), Plasmodium (Figure 4), and dinoflagellates (Figure 5) are classified as Alveolates.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A micrograph of several slipper-shaped paramecium cells, each with cilia and feeding grooves visible.
Figure 4: Microscopic image of plasmodium growing in an animal cell
Figure 5: A micrograph of dinoflagellates.

pageData.text: Stramenopiles (sometimes called Heterokonts) are characterized by the presence of two flagella when flagella are present (not all Stramenopiles have flagella). One flagellum of the pair often has hair-like projections. Many Stramenopiles, such as diatoms (Figure 6) and multicellular kelp, are photosynthetic, and they range in size from microscopic to over 80 meters tall. Oomycetes (water molds) are also included in this group. Stramenopiles were long thought to be closely related to fungi, but recent evidence suggests that they are not as closely related to fungi as previously thought.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: A micrograph of a mixture of diatoms with highly variable shapes.

pageData.question: Some euglenids are photosynthetic. Where does this photosynthetic ability come from?

options.text: recombination of genes with photosynthetic bacteria
a mutation in genes for cellular respiration

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Secondary endosymbiosis occurs when one organism (such as a euglenid) engulfs another organism (such as green algae) that over evolutionary time becomes part of and necessary for the life of the original organism.

pageData.question: Which of the following is true about nutrient acquisition in protists?

options.text: Some heterotrophic protists engulf other organisms entirely.
Mixotrophs use cilia to stir up the surrounding water for food.
Photosynthesis in protists developed only by secondary endosymbiosis.
Heterotrophic protists always absorb their food.
A photoautotrophic protist consumes algae for food.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Heterotrophic protists can either absorb nutrients or engulf other organisms.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Protists obtain their nutrition in many ways. Some protists, such as algae, are photoautotrophs, which produce food (glucose) through photosynthesis. Others are heterotrophs, which obtain food from their environment. Heterotrophic protists can either absorb nutrients, as is the case with slime molds such as Myxogastria, or they can engulf other organisms, as is the case with Amoeba. Some ciliates and flagellates use their appendages to filter-feed, using them to create water currents that help them to engulf their food. Some protists can both produce food and obtain food from their environment. These protists, such as Euglena, are called mixotrophs. The photosynthetic ability of euglenids comes from their secondary endosymbiosis with green algae: the protists have engulfed the algae and, over evolutionary time, the algae have become part of and necessary for the life of the protists.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Protists obtain their nutrition in many ways. Some protists, such as algae, are photoautotrophs, which produce food (glucose) through photosynthesis. Others are heterotrophs, which obtain food from their environment. Heterotrophic protists can either absorb nutrients, as is the case with slime molds such as Myxogastria, or they can engulf other organisms, as is the case with Amoeba. Some ciliates and flagellates use their appendages to filter-feed, using them to create water currents that help them to engulf their food. Some protists can both produce food and obtain food from their environment. These protists, such as Euglena, are called mixotrophs. The photosynthetic ability of euglenids comes from their secondary endosymbiosis with green algae: the protists have engulfed the algae and, over evolutionary time, the algae have become part of and necessary for the life of the protists.

pageData.text: C. Many have filose , which are very thin, hair-like pseudopodia. They include the Cercozoa, Foraminifera and Radiolaria (Figure 7). Most fossilized protists are Rhizarians due to the shells that many of these organisms have, which form siliceous scales, plates, and sometimes spines. Rhizarians are sometimes grouped with and Stramenopiles, forming the SAR supergroup.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: A micrograph of radiolaria.

pageData.text: D. (also called Plantae) are organisms that possess double membranebound chloroplasts due to . Archaeplastids include land plants as well as protists. The protists in this group include red algae (i.e., Porphyra) and green algae, i.e., Volvox (Figure 8). Recent research has brought the of Archaeplastida into doubt.

pageData.altText: Figure 8: A micrograph of two circular volvox cells. Each cell has several smaller circular green internal structures.

pageData.text: E. are characterized by having only one flagellum when flagella are present. This group includes animals, fungi, and protists. The protists in this group are:
, which are characterized by lobe-shaped . Amoeba proteus (Figure 9) and slime molds are classified as Amoebozoans.

pageData.altText: Figure 9: An image of a labeled amoeba. Pseudopodia are shown protruding from one end.

pageData.text: Labeled amoeba.jpg by Andrei Savitsky is available under Creative Commons Attribution4.0 International License at https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%B1%D1%8B_Mayorella_sp.jpg

, which may be motile or nonmotile. Motile Opisthokonts possess a single posterior flagellum. This group includes the Choanoflagellates, which are the protists that are most closely related to humans. Choanoflagellates are almost identical in shape and function with the choanocytes (collar cells) of sponges, as shown in Figure 10.

pageData.altText: Figure 10: A protist choanoflagellate cell and a sponge choanocyte cell. Both cells have the same overall shape and single posterior flagellum.

pageData.text: Choanoflagellate_and_choanocyte.png by Clark MA, Choi J and Douglas M is available under Creative Commons Attribution4.0 International License athttps://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Choanoflagellate_and_choanocyte.png

pageData.question: Which of the following types of evidence is most responsible for Protista losing its validity as a kingdom in modern classification systems?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Today, modern classification systems based on molecular data have changed the classification schemes for many organisms, including protists, which are no longer considered a valid kingdom.

pageData.question: Which of the following is true about the species referred to as “protists”?

options.text: The group does not include all descendants of a common ancestor.
All members of the group are easily described as animal-like, plant-like, or fungi-like.
The group does not share a common ancestor.
Based on molecular evidence, the group is most closely related to the kingdom Plantae.
Members of the group that were called “animal-like” are now in the kingdom Animalia.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Protists are paraphyletic, meaning that all members of the group have a common ancestor, but the group does not necessarily include all descendants of that ancestor.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which group is characterized by a feeding groove located on one side of the cell?
Which of these is the group of Chromalveolates that includes diatoms, kelp, and oomycetes?
Which group is characterized by having only one flagellum when flagella are present?
To which group do red and green algae belong?
To which group do animals and fungi, as well as certain protists, belong?
Which group is characterized by lobe-shaped pseudopodia?

Obtain all needed materials. You may want to use this drawing template to organize your drawings.
Complete the virtual microscope tutorial before starting the activities in this investigation.
In Activity 1, you will use the virtual microscope to observe prepared slides of protists.

In the first part of Activity 2, you will virtually prepare an infusion of timothy hay and culture microorganisms in the infusion. In the second part of the activity, you will prepare three wet mount microscope slides, each from a different depth of the infusion culture.
In Activity 3, you will use the virtual microscope to observe the protists in the wet mount slides you prepared in Activity 2.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

text:
The hay included as part of the culture medium provided a food source for bacteria. Bacteria are a good food source for some types of protists.
  1. Explain which group(s) of protists would not have survived because they have no way to produce their own food.
1. Explain which group(s) of protists would have survived without this food source.
Where in your culture container would you most likely to find photosynthetic protists?  Explain why.

data.title: Alveolates
data.content: A group of protists characterized by alveoli (sacs) near the cell surface

data.title: Amoebozoans
data.content: A group of protists characterized by lobe-shaped pseudopodia

data.title: Archaeplastids
data.content: A group of organisms that possess double membrane-bound chloroplasts due to primary endosymbiosis; also called Plantae; includes land plants and protists

data.title: Chromalveolates
data.content: A group of protists that include photosynthetic organisms, such as diatoms, brown algae, and disease agents in animals and plants

data.title: Excavates
data.content: A group of protists that are defined by an asymmetrical appearance with a feeding groove that is “excavated” on one side

data.title: Heterotroph
data.content: An organism that cannot produce its own food but rather takes nutrition from other sources of organic carbon, mainly plant or animal matter

data.title: Mitochondria
data.content: The cell organelles that produce energy for the cell in the form of ATP

data.title: Monophyly
data.content: A taxonomic group composed of a common ancestor and all of its lineal descendants

data.title: Opisthokonts
data.content: A group of protists characterized by a single posterior flagellum; members of this group can be motile or nonmotile

data.title: Paraphyletic
data.content: Describes a taxonomic group in which all the members of the group have a common ancestor, but the group does not necessarily include all descendants of that ancestor

data.title: Photoautotroph
data.content: Organisms that produce food (glucose) through photosynthesis

data.title: Phylogenetics
data.content: The study of the evolutionary history and relationships among or within groups of organisms

data.title: Primary endosymbiosis
data.content: The process of the engulfment of a prokaryote by a eukaryote cell

data.title: Pseudopodia
data.content: A temporary protrusion of the surface of an amoeboid cell used for movement and feeding

data.title: Rhizarians
data.content: A group of protists that includes many of the amoebas, most of which have threadlike or needle-like pseudopodia

data.title: Secondary endosymbiosis
data.content: The process of the engulfment of a eukaryote cell by another eukaryote cell

data.title: Unikonts
data.content: A group of organisms characterized by a single flagellum when flagella are present; includes animals, fungi, and protists
